title: A Comparison of Techniques for Name-based Private Record Linkage
segmentation: So this is work that I did together with my master student.
Poal grows Bala, well graduated in April and now he works for IBM in Dublin, OH.
Also known as not the cool Dublin so I will be presenting that and these are his slides not mine.
Before we get started, one thing I wanted to explain a little bit about is when I graduated with my undergrad degree I worked for 10 years for my government and my background is in cyber security.

But when I decided to pursue a PhD, I could not do a dissertation topic on cyber security because the guy that I worked for wanted to, you know, like to classify things and I could just see myself in job interviews for faculty positions, saying trust me, my work was great, but I can't tell you what it was, so I didn't think that would workout very well.
So my PhD dissertation was an ontology alignment and I still do a lot of work on ontology alignment, an coreference resolution.

So now that I'm a faculty member, I've looked for ways that I can combine these two backgrounds and so that's led me to look at privacy concerns of big data in the semantic web, and that's kind of where this work well where this work is going.

So one day, about a year ago, gentleman from LexisNexis walked into my office and he had a very interesting use case his this was roughly a year after the big breaches at Target in the United States Postal Service happened.
Also, the Office of Personnel Management.
So now someone has all of my details 'cause I work for the government, right?
So these attacks that had happened, they were attacks on data at rest.

As opposed to data in translator data in motion right so these were attacks where people had gotten access to a database on a server not, you know, snooped on data as it was being passed between two different locations.

Similarly, the use case that the LexisNexis was looking at was one that's not often studied in this area, at least not that I can find, and the idea here is that a data provider has a database that he is charging other people data consumers to access this database, right?
So the people who are querying the database have paid for the right to query this database and access the information, and we are making sure that we.
We're only letting the right people query the database with a traditional access control mechanism, but what he was interested in is this idea that we wanted to protect the data while it was at rest.
So we want the data in the database to be encrypted at all times, both in the database and in memory when we're responding to these queries.
So application scenario kind of clear OK.
Alright, so as I said, this is not maybe the common thing that's looked at when people look at private record linkage.

In particular, most of the existing approaches are targeting scenarios that are in or they're targeting scenarios that have characteristics that are not relevant to the one that we're talking about here.
In some cases, these characteristics are requiring more computationally or communication intensive approaches.
Then we need in this case.

So they're not as efficient as we could be doing, and in other cases they are allowing the data to be in cleartext in places where we don't want it to be, so they're less secure in ways in other ways, right?
So in particular, a lot of the existing work is assuming that the people involved with the private record linkage, so the data producer and consumer don't trust one another.
That's not the case here, write another.
Oh, and because of that many times, there is a suggestion that we should use a third party, right?
In particular, they didn't want to use a third party in this approach because the data producer is making you know this data commercially available for money.
They don't want to share, sort of the Golden goose with a third party provider, right?
And in another case.
Or in many other researches, researchers work in this area they're looking at.
Can they prevent the data provider from learning the queries?
So in this case we're not concerned about that.
The data consumer who is querying the database we're protecting.
They're not worried about the data provider knowing what they're querying for.
The other thing that I want to mention is that while this work in this particular application was focused on databases, this many of these.
Approaches I'm going to discuss in this talk, they apply equally well to coreference resolution of.
Of linked data, right?
OK.
So as I said, there's some existing work in this field.
Third party approaches I think, are fairly straightforward.
The provider is going to share their data with a third party and then the consumer will query the data from there.
That's not what we're looking at here to party approaches.
These tend to be more complex and computationally demanding than what we need for our use case that I'm describing here so.

An example of a two party approaches instead of when a query comes in and we're comparing the name being queried for the string being queried for with all of the records in our data set instead, what we would do is we would compare all of the names in our data set with a publicly available group of names and sort of been all of the names based on the similarity value between those names and the names in this public data set.
And then the other data provider or the data query?
Or would do the same thing and we would use the triangle inequality.

So this is very computationally intensive and.
You know, not not our goal for this.
Or not appropriate?
This work, So what did we use if these other things aren't appropriate?
We considered some string similarity metrics that will work even on encrypted strings.
So our approach here is that we're going to encrypt all of the strings in our database.
In particular, the names in our database with the symmetric key encryption algorithm.
So not the public private key kind, just a symmetric kind.
We have one key, so we're going to encrypt all the names in our database, and then when queries come in, we're going to encrypt the name from the query with the same key that we used to encrypt.
All the names in the database, and then we're going to do the query on the encrypted names as opposed to the plaintext names so.
This is tricky, obviously, because the way that encryption algorithms work.
If there's a small difference in the plaintext string that you're encrypting, the ciphertext will be very different.
That's kind of one of the key points of good encryption algorithms, right?
However, that's not good for this use case, because when we're querying on names a lot of times names are spelled slightly differently.
Maybe there are typos in the names, and so we want to be able to not only query on the exact value, but get names that are so similar that they.
May possibly be what we're looking for, so we wanted to do, you know, fuzzy matching on names, not just exact matching on names.
And because this is our goal, there are not all string metrics are going to be appropriate for determining if a name is matching the one in the query.
In particular, we need string metrics that don't need access to every individual letter in the string, because if we had that.
For example, encrypted every character in the string separately.
That would basically just be a classical substitution cipher, and those are people do those as puzzles to crack, right?
So that would be not appropriate, so we need to find string similarity metrics that can work with this use case, and we did not propose these.
Originally, these have been proposed by other researchers, so the.
The contribution of this work is basically been a very thorough efficiency and accuracy analysis of using soundex and Q grams for the type of application that I'm talking to you about.

So soundex I don't know if you guys are already familiar with this, But the idea behind Soundex is that we're going to encode strings based on approved giving letters that are commonly sound the same the same code.
So for example.
It's really hard to read, but normally like D&T for example, these are often said the same or sound somewhat similar, so we would give them the same numeric code so you have a string.

You compute it soundex code, you encrypt the soundex code as well as the name, and then when you're responding to queries, you're querying an exact match, but it's exact match of the soundex code and several different names will map to the same soundex code, so theoretically.
You're getting back all the names that you want to.
That's the idea was sounddogs Q grams.

The idea is that we're going to break the name up into groups of Q letters at a time and we're going to encrypt each group of Q letters separately and store that in the database glammed altogether stored in the database as well as the encrypted name, and then when we're looking to see if a name matches the one that's being queried for, we're going to encrypt the query name in the same way and then compare the two encrypted strings.
Based on either the Jaccard metric or the dice metric, which are just two set similarity metrics.
OK.
We compared the approach of, you know, performing encrypted queries with these two string similarity metrics to that of performing queries on unencrypted data using Levinstein and George.
R. Winkler which are two very standard edit distance metrics.
So they count the number of insertions, deletions, or levinstein consonant, more insertions, deletions, or substitutions needed.
To change one string to another string and general looks at the number of common characters as well as transpositions in the string.
So we're going to compare these things, padded Q grams.

The idea here is that Q grams that metric has kind of a problem in that if you compare, for example, the words stop with the word post, you're going to get an exact match because they have the same letters, even though they're in a different order, so.
So let me just back up a little bit.

OK, so basically the padded kilograms approaches that you're going to add a special character that doesn't appear in the data at the beginning of every name and a different one at the end of every name.
And so you're basically marking where the beginning and the end are in.
That sort of helps to alleviate that problem.
OK, so the hardest part by far about this project was finding a data set to use.

It is very, very hard to find a publicly available real world data set of a bunch of names that is not completely US specific, so we wanted names from all over the world in the same data set and that is very very difficult to find.
So because of privacy concerns I would guess so instead we turn to this jacot tool which was developed by Ken Tran.
This is an amazing synthetic data generation tool for PII or personally identifiable information.
It is very seated with a very realistic list of names and then it can also generate data besides name data or string data.
Also numeric data, categorical data and it can require that relationships hold between the data field, so it's pretty impressive.
So this is what we used for this study.
Quick note on how we counted correct versus false positive and false negatives.
If we're querying for a name, and we find that exact name, then that's correct.
Obviously, if we're querying for that name and it's there, but we don't find it, that's a false negative.
If it's querying for that name and we find it, but we find five other names too, then we get one correct and five false positives.
So here's what we found out from that.
All of these combinations let me just go back a second, so we.
A whole bunch of different variations.
We looked at different types of corruption of names, so character edits or where it's like a misspelling where we should have one letter and we have a different letter.
Keyboard errors are kind of similar, but they're like errors that you would more commonly make when you're typing on a keyboard.

So letters that are next to one another and things like that, OCR errors or errors you would get when doing optical character recognition and phonetic errors are when you would spell things wrong because they sound kind of similar.
So the example here is Catherine with a C versus OK.
So we tried all of these different kinds of errors.
We introduced them at the rate of either one per record or two per record.
The corruption rate for the data set.
The entire database was either two percent, 5% or 10%.
So combining all of these things, we had like 30 different.
TR.
Groups, I guess you would call it, which resulted in a lot of graphs, so I'm just going to kind of hit the high points here.
The first thing that we found out is soundex is completely not viable for this approach, but padded Q grams are both Q grams impacted.
Q Grams perform fairly well at this task pattern.
Q Grams performed very slightly better.
Both of these, though the accuracy was in on the encrypted names, querying on the encrypted names was roughly equivalent to the accuracy using Levinstein or Jaro on the unencrypted names.

Soundex was pretty horrible, so you would think that it would at least do good on phonetic edits, and yet it only has 60% accuracy in when there's only one one problem per name, so that's pretty terrible.
So.
We didn't look much further into that.
Dice, so I told you when your computer comparing two sets of programs, you need to set similarity metric and we looked at DICE or Jaccard dice performed very slightly better than Jacquard.
The reason why being that dice slightly more prioritizes things that are in common, as opposed to penalizing for things that are different.
So the other thing is that you can't just set your threshold values for what you're going to consider a viable match as you would if you were querying on unencrypted data.
The threshold values need to be much lower if you're using encrypted data, got it?
The other thing is that obviously some types of errors were harder to deal with than others.

In particular, the optical character recognition kind of errors were very challenging to deal with, but they were challenging to deal with for all our all approaches, both for encrypted strings, an unencrypted strings, and the main reason for this is because there are a lot of times where 2 two letters such as CL might be converted to a single character like D. And the reverse is also true.
A single character like M might be broken into 2 characters like RN, right next to each other, and this is harder for the string similarity metrics to deal with.
And then, as if we ever introduced more than one error per name, the performance went down, kind of precipitously.
And then we looked a little bit at the efficiency.
So all of the string metrics that we looked at have the same time complexity.
They're all order NM, where N is the length of 1 string and M is the length of the other string that you're comparing.
But there are differences in the runtime because of constant level differences.
For example, Jaro only considers 2 characters to be matching if they are transposed.
If they're within a window of half the length of the string.
So that causes a different.
Constant factor of time complexity compared to levinstein.
The other thing that we looked at was the number of the records in the database, but this was suggested by the reviewers of this paper.
However, we're comparing every name to every other name, so it's also quadratic.
So what we found out here is that there's not a huge efficiency penalty from using the encrypted string metrics on the encrypted strings versus on the unencrypted strings.
Levinstein was really, really slow five times slower than anything else.
We use these second string library implementation of this, so it's possible that maybe that implementation is not so good.
I mean it is more.
Intensive than these others, but I was surprised at the level of the difference.
OK.
The other thing to note is that as Q increases accuracy decreases.
But here we have a tradeoff.
That's pretty important, right?
So as Q increases, accuracy decreases.
But as Q increases, privacy increases right?

If Q is very low, then you become more vulnerable to a frequency analysis attack, so we continue this work and we did a rather extensive frequency analysis attacks study on this approach, and from that we found that the.
The best kind of balance between efficiency and privacy of this approach is when Q = 3 totally.
Finishing up side.
So in conclusion, this work is indicated that padded programs are a good approach for this use case.
Soundex is completely not smaller.
Values of Q are more accurate, but less secure, so Q = 3 strikes a good balance.

Here the accuracy and time penalties for privacy preserving linkage when compared to standard language techniques or small, and it is extremely difficult to find appropriate datasets for this work, particularly that are not US centric.
And that's all I've got.
